entry.title: A lemma from Ross
entry.content:
Just for my own memory, here is a (very intuitive) lemma I struggled to prove in Ross in Huangshan where I stayed up super late with Xqy (to whom I’m grateful) discussing and eventually proving it.

Statement as follows:

\[ orall g,k\in\mathbb{Z}\ with\ gcd(g,k)=1,\ it\ holds\ orall t\in\mathbb{Z}\ \exists a\in\mathbb{Z}\ such\ that\ gcd(t,g+ak)=1.\]

Proof:

Fix such \(g,k\in\mathbb{Z}\) and arbitrary \(t\in\mathbb{Z}\). Factorize \(t=\prod_{i=1}^np_i^{e_i}\).

Consider \(p_i^{e_i}\) for any \(1\leq i\leq n\):

If \(p_i\mid k\) and \(p_i mid g\), then \(gcd(p_i^{e_i},g+ak)=1\) for any \(a\in\mathbb{Z}\).

If \(p_i mid k\), then \(gcd(p_i^{e_i},k)=1\). Proceed as follows:

Let set \(T=\{a\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{0\}: a<p_i^{e_i}\}\) and \(S=\{g+ak:a\in T\}\).

Let function \(f:S ightarrow T\) by \(g+ak\mapsto g+ak\mod{p_i^{e_i}}\).

If \(g+a_1k \equiv g+a_2k\mod{p_i^{e_i}}\) (and we know \(gcd(p_i^{e_i},k)=1\)), then \(p_i^{e_i}\mid (a_2-a_1)\).

This then implies \(a_2=a_1\) by definition of \(T\), so \(f\) is injective.

By injectivity, we have \(T = f(S)\), which then implies \(\exists a_i\in T\) such that \(g+a_ik\equiv 1\mod{p_i^{e_i}}\) and so \(gcd(g+a_ik, p_i^{e_i})=1\).

Finally, by Chinese Reminder Theorem (which I completely forget now), we get \(\exists a\in\mathbb{Z}\) such that \(a\equiv a_i \mod{p_i^{e_i}}\) for all \(i\) where \(p_i mid k\). And for this \(a\), one can check \(gcd(g+ak,t)=1\).

entry.title: Inequality for norms of matrix producted with projection

link.title: Inequality for norms of matrix producted with projection

entry.content:
Suppose we have an arbitrary \(m​\)-by-\(n​\) matrix \(M​\) and any subspaces \(A\subseteq B​\) in \(n​\)-dim. Let \(P_{A,B}​\) denote the projection matrix to \(A,B​\) respectively. We want to compare the norms of \(MP_A​\) and \(MP_B​\) that are related to the singular values.

First and most obvious, the operator norm (induced by some arbitrary vector norm):

\[\begin{align*} \|MP_A\|_{op} \equiv \sup_{x\in A,\|x\|=1}\|Mx\| \leq \|MP_B\|_{op}. \end{align*}\]

Second, the Frobenius norm, observe \(MP_A=MP_BP_A\):

\[\begin{align*} \|MP_A\|_F^2 &= \|(MP_BP_A)^T\|_F^2\\ &= \|P_A^TP_B^TM^T\|_F^2\\ &\leq \|P_A^T\|_{op}\|P_B^TM^T\|_F^2\\ &=\|MP_B\|_F^2\quad\quad\quad\text{when $\|P_A^T\|_{op}=\|P_A\|_{op}=1$, i.e. $A$ is not null space} \end{align*}\]

Third, the nuclear norm follows immediately from the above observation:

\[\begin{align*} \|MP_A\|_* = \|MP_BP_A\|_* \leq \|MP_B\|_* \end{align*}\]

since \(\|QV\|_*=\sum_i\sigma_i(QV)\leq \sum_i\sigma_i(Q)\|V\|_{op} = \|Q\|_*\|P\|_{op}\) where operator norm gives the largest singular value.
